description: Designed with the goal of making Sixpack A/B testing Android applications easy and painless, sixpack-java has a straightforward API and an easy setup process that should make measuring and analyzing your application design decisions a breeze.
title: Sixpack-java: A/B Testing for Android and Java Apps

description: This post starts with two real examples (one trivial and another more complex) to see how the Data Binding could be useful for developing Android apps.
title: Two-way Android data binding

description: Dan Lew writes about using RxJava's defer() as a tool for ensuring Observable code runs when subscribed (rather than when created).
title: Deferring Observable code until subscription in RxJava

description: In addition to ViewPager integration, Prism v1 also has triggering from the Palette support library in an optional module. This article shows how to connect this all up.

description: The data binding library will allow us to be more declarative in the way we work with our views.  The author shows how it allows for lower friction unit testing for view and application logic.
title: MVVM on Android using the Data Binding Library

description: RxJava is a great library, but it’s not easy to get started. The article outlines different approaches to unit testing Observables.

description: Working with multi-modules project, it is very useful to centralize the dependencies, especially the support libraries. This article shows a good way to do this.

description: You can’t directly get a list of the views inside a ViewGroup, but in Kotlin, there is a way to prepare any kind of data to work with collection operations.
title: Functional operations over Views in ViewGroup using Kotlin

description: The author goes through a semi-realistic example and explains the thought behind some information hiding strategies in apps and why they may not be as effective as you might initially hope.

description: We are building PSPDFKit for Android using RxJava & C++ 14. It's a challenging project that is used in many apps and there's plenty of work to be done. We have a talented team, who enjoy the benefits of working in a remote environment. If you're up for a challenge, send us your resume.

description: Crew is a messaging and productivity app for workplaces in the deskless economy. Crew replaces text messages, which dominate the service economy with an easy to use app. Crew introduces concepts like ticketing and task management to workers who have never used business software in their roles.
